CD16 on NK cells recognises the Fc portion of antibodies bound to the surface and kills the target cell [37,65,66,67]. evasion mechanisms by viruses emphasise the importance of complement in anti-viral immunity, as reviewed elsewhere [68,69]. the detection of VDR abundance throughout the immune system has directed vitamin D research into the area of immunology. the observation that VDR expression is regulated by immune signalling. the detection of CYP27B1 expression by immune cells has directed vitamin D research into the area of immunology. extra-renal 1-hydroxylation in cells such as monocytes and macrophages is regulated primarily by immune inputs. this renders the immune system responsive to circulating levels of 25(OH)D and allows the sustained and potentially beneficial production of 1,25(OH)2D during an immune response. ligation of TLR4 by LPS up-regulated CYP27B1 expression in monocytes [93,94] extra-renal expression of CYP27B1 has been shown to be possible. other TLRs or alternate PRRs may promote extra-renal expression of CYP27B1. extra-renal 1,25(OH)2D synthesis has been shown to be regulated by TLR ligation. active form of LL-37 is cleaved by serine protease 3 in neutrophils. LL-37 is present in epithelial cells, monocytes, NK cells, B-cells and T-cells. cathelicidins are multifunctional antimicrobial peptides, and the sole form in humans is hCAP-18. proximal promoter region of deFB4 gene also contains a VDRE. 1,25(OH)2D can upregulate expression of -defensin 2. vitamin D has been demonstrated to modulate the innate immune system. vitamin D induces autophagy by regulating pathways such as Bcl-2, mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR), phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase complex, and cathelicidin production. expression of TLR2 and TLR4 is inhibited in monocytes, resulting in impaired downstream signalling and hyporesponsiveness to PAMPS. dendritic cells are the most potent antigen-presenting cells. they have a direct effect on lymphocyte activation and induction of the adaptive immune response. addition of 1,25(OH)2D has been demonstrated to inhibit DC differentiation, maturation and antigen presentation. DC production of IL-12 and IL-23 inhibited by 1,25(OH)2D. IL-12, as well as stimulating the development of Th1 T-cells, also inhibits the development of Th2 cells. IL-10 is a cytokine with pleiotropic effects in immunoregulation. 1,25(OH)2D has also been shown to have direct effects on T-cells. production of IL-2, IFN-, TNF-, IL-17 and IL-21 are all inhibited. production of IL-2, IFN-, TNF-, IL-17 and IL-21 are also directly altered. vitamin D may affect other lymphocyte subsets, with fewer invariant natural killer (iNKT) cells and CD8+ T-cells from MS patients secreting less IFN- and TNF- and more IL-5 and TGF- following 1,25(OH)2D treatment. however, the mechanisms behind any potential beneficial role of vitamin D are unclear, with conflicting cellular studies on the effects of vitamin D on Th2 cells [170,171]. 1,25(OH)2D has diverse and extensive effects on the immune compartment. monocytes producing more LL-37 and -defensin, with increased NOD2 expression and autophagy. also producing diminished amounts of inflammatory cytokines, with decreased expression of TLR2 and TLR4. STAT1 is also phosphorylated and able to translocate into the nucleus. incubation with vitamin D metabolites did not alter this effect. treatment with vitamin D did, however, enhance secretion of CXCL8 and CXCL10. these molecules are pro-inflammatory chemokines responsible for the recruitment of immune cells to the site of infection. cells infected with RSV for 24 h had decreased protein levels of IB. increase in IB results in NF-B remaining inactive in the cytoplasm. vitamin D inhibits RSV induction of NF-B-driven IFN- and CXCL10 secretion. 1,25(OH)2D is able to decrease levels of phosphorylated STAT-1 (pSTAT-1) and increase IB protein levels, with subsequent diminished expression of interferon regulatory factor 1 (IRF1), IRF7, IFN- and CXCL8 mRNA. a number of studies have been carried out in calves, looking at the association between vitamin D and bovine RSV (BRSV) vitamin D treatment has been shown to increase secretion of the pro-inflammatory cytokine IL-12p40 following BRSV infection [189] no effect was observed on T-cell cytokine production [190], or IFN-, CXCL8, TNF-, IL-1 or IL-6 secretion [189]. a simple and cost-effective prevention strategy is desirable. the antimicrobial peptides LL-37 and human -defensin 2 have anti-viral properties against influenza virus. this may be another mechanism by which vitamin D exerts antiviral effects on influenza virus infection. the majority of work into vitamin D has been investigating the potential use of vitamin D as an adjuvant in influenza vaccines. vitamin D metabolites are pro-inflammatory chemokines responsible for the recruitment of immune cells to the site of infection. vitamin D deficiency linked to RSV susceptibility, with low cord blood plasma concentrations of 25(OH)D related to RSV incidence in the first year of life.
